output.project: IoT-based Outdoor Air Quality Monitoring System for Smart Cities
output.concept: Low-power, weatherproof, scalable sensor network for real-time air quality data across urban areas using IoT protocols.
research-pap: Mead, M.I., et al. 2013. The Use of Low-Cost Sensor Technology for Personal and Local Air Quality Monitoring. Atmospheric Environment.
Snyder, E.G., et al. 2013. The Use of Low-Cost Sensor Technology for Air Quality Monitoring and Exposure Assessment. Atmospheric Environment.
Castell, N., et al. 2017. A robust monitoring network based on low-cost sensors for urban air quality. Environmental Science & Technology.
DalMaso, A., et al. 2020. IoT-based air quality monitoring using LoRaWAN: design and deployment. IEEE Internet of Things Journal.

problems_overall.problem: Power autonomy for continuous outdoor operation
problems_overall.suggested_solution: Optimize duty cycle, enable deep sleep modes, and select energy-dense storage with solar charging.

problems_overall.problem: Sensor drift and cross-sensitivity to humidity/temperature
problems_overall.suggested_solution: Implement periodic calibration with reference stations and algorithmic compensation; batch-install collocations.

problems_overall.problem: Data reliability in dense urban RF environments
problems_overall.suggested_solution: In-network buffering, multi-network fallback, and time-synchronization with calibrated clocks.

options.name: All-in-one multi-parameter sensor module (PM2.5/PM10, VOC, CO2, RH/Temp)
options.why_it_works: Simplifies integration and reduces BOM; factory calibration data aids accuracy.

options.name: PM optical sensor + electrochemical gas sensors + RH/Temp
options.why_it_works: Modular sensing allows tailored pollutant targets and calibration strategy.

options.name: Optical PM counter + NDIR CO2 sensor
options.why_it_works: Provides high-quality PM measurements with accurate CO2 data.

options.name: MEMS-based gas sensors with humidity compensation
options.why_it_works: Low power and small form factor suitable for dense networks.

options.name: Rechargeable Li-ion battery with MPPT solar charging and BMS
options.why_it_works: Enables true off-grid operation with predictable energy supply.

options.name: Battery-only operation with deep-sleep optimization
options.why_it_works: Minimizes energy draw for ultra-low-power sensors.

options.name: Power over infrastructure (PoE/AC backup)
options.why_it_works: Leverages existing urban infrastructure where available.

options.name: NB-IoT / LTE-M (LPWAN)
options.why_it_works: Wide coverage, low power, good urban penetration.

options.name: LoRaWAN
options.why_it_works: Low-power, long-range radio ideal for dense deployments with gateways.

options.name: Wi-Fi
options.why_it_works: High bandwidth in coverage-rich areas; simple integration with local gateways.

options.name: 32-bit ARM Cortex-M MCU with RTOS (e.g., STM32)
options.why_it_works: Low power, deterministic control, adequate sensor drivers.

options.name: Embedded Linux SBC (e.g., Raspberry Pi Zero W)
options.why_it_works: High compute, easier software stack, ML inference capability.

options.name: ESP32-based microcontroller
options.why_it_works: Cost-effective, integrated connectivity, suitable for moderate workloads.

options.name: IP65-rated polycarbonate enclosure with gasket and flush vents
Aluminum weatherproof enclosure with heat sink
options.why_it_works: Better thermal management; robust for long-term outdoor use.

options.name: 3D-printed enclosure with IP-rated gaskets and replaceable filters
options.why_it_works: Rapid, low-cost customization; easy field service.
cons: Requires careful design to meet IP rating

output.cost: Estimated per-node cost (sensors, electronics, enclosure): USD 120–650; pilot deployment (20–50 nodes) USD 24k–32.5k hardware; ongoing maintenance extra.
output.skills: Embedded hardware design, sensor calibration, PCB layout, firmware development, network integration, data analytics, cloud deployment, and field deployment planning.
suggestions: Prototype with off-the-shelf modules to reduce risk and accelerate testing.
Establish a sensor calibration plan with reference-grade collocation sites.
Perform network coverage analysis early to guide gateway placement and choice of communication protocol.
Design for modularity so sensors and radios can be swapped as technology evolves.
Implement robust OTA updates and data validation pipelines to ensure long-term reliability.
